Frieze

Frieze Art Fair, in eight years, has become a leading fixture in the art world's annual calendar. Every October, over 150 of the most dynamic contemporary art galleries from 29 countries gather in Regent's Park, London, to show over 1000 artists' work (Thumbnail credit Frieze Art Fair 2010, courtesy of Linda Nylind for Frieze)

A pagan adventure

By James Bithell

A <em>MUSE</em> photo feature (Thumbnail credit Photo: Sam Newsome)

The puppet masters of the music industry

Is it all sex, drugs and rock and roll? Do stars make the music business, or is it the other way around? Oliver Trotman speaks to band manager Dick O'Dell and discovers what drives one of the most popular, competitive and profitable industries (Thumbnail credit Natasha Khan of Bat For Lashes)

Children of the revolution?

Students have a reputation of rebelling against the system. Mia de Graaf looks at the history of student politics and exercising the right to make your voice heard (Thumbnail credit Warwick students protest in 1975. Photo: Jake Bernard)

Dead man walking

The death penalty is always an issue that provokes debate. But Camilla Apcar questions its worth after speaking to a man exonerated after 19 years on death row (Thumbnail credit Inside an American prison. Photo credit: Jake Bernard)

Coming up for air

By James Bithell

Stephen Gill's photography reflects a wide range of interests, from birds, animals and music. Lowenna Waters speaks to this most contemporary of artists (Thumbnail credit Some of Gill's work. All images credit: Stephen Gill photography)

Rebel, Rebel

Controversial choreographer Michael Clark has reinvented just about every aspect of ballet. Mia de Graaf hears his take on the freedom of creativity (Thumbnail credit Michael Clark. All photos credit: Jake Walters)

Freshers' Food Diary

Contrary to your tutor's beliefs, man cannot live on knowledge alone. Here are some tried and tested student recipies lovingly collected by <em>Nouse</em>'s expert chefs for your benefit alone

Lectures? What lectures?

It turns out UCAS may not have been entirely truthful about the whole university experience. Liv Evans offers a survival guide for the bemused, confused and slightly misused (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

How to be indispensable

Ladies and gentlemen, intern and job applications are officially open. As we face one of the most competitive employment markets yet, India Richards investigates the best way to succeed during internships

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em>'s guide to a night out in York

Terry Waite: a man in the firing line

By James Bithell

Victoria Lee meets the man who was at the centre of a media and political storm when he was held hostage in Lebanon between 1987 and 1991

Frank Gardner

By James Bithell

As a BBC security correspondent, one is expected to put themselves in the firing line. Liv Evans and Mia de Graaf speak to someone willing to do anything for the story

A doll's life: a choice or a consequence?

By James Bithell

Will it ever be acceptable for little girls to dream of being pole dancers? Richard Lemmer talks to the York Pole Exercise Club and Natasha Walter, author of Living Dolls: The Return of Sexism about the line between degregation and liberation

Should private ownership be a public issue?

Britain has some of the strongest gun legislation in the world. Ben Gascoyne asks whether laws designed to protect the public have gone too far?

Fresh out of Asia

By James Bithell

Camilla Apcar talks to the organiser of the Elephant Parade in London about wildlife, charity and vandalism

Beauty and the beast

The bikini round may no longer be an essential part of entering beauty pageants, but will they ever be about more than appearances? Kate Goligher investigates

Photography.

Winning photos for the Nouse Photography Competition 2010 (Thumbnail credit Best Overall Photo; George Lowther)

Getting the 'Fred' Finish

By James Bithell

After designing Gaga's infamous Telephone hat, Fred Butler's star is on the rise. Liam O'Brien asks just how you turn paper and plastics into fashion (Thumbnail credit Lady Gaga in the 'Telephone' video)

Delusions of grandeur

What place do historic houses have in the modern world? Liv Evans finds that stately homes have an enduring appeal and are still relevant in today's society (Thumbnail credit Castle Howard)

Losing touch

Being confirmed as mentally ill was one of the least worrying moments of my life (Thumbnail credit Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

How the other half play

Sam Lawson investigates the sports that take place in some of Britain's most exclusive institutions. (Thumbnail credit Students play the Eton Wall Game, Image: Eton College)

Would you let the world know your secret?

By James Bithell

Frank Warren receives hundreds of postcards expressing people's darkest moments. Camilla Apcar investigates what led him to found the PostSecret project (Thumbnail credit Frank at home, surrounded by postcards)

Dirty $exy Money

At the end of this term, a new bunch of York graduates will depart to take on the world. Liv Evans discovers how to get exactly what you want from life (Thumbnail credit What our generation hopes to achieve?)

Street Angels

By James Bithell

Who's there when a good night goes wrong? Sian Turner investigates an organisation which helps those in difficulty in York's city centre every weekend (Thumbnail credit A street angel in action)

What does your future hold?

By James Bithell

Despite scepticism surrounding the pyschic industry, it continues to grow. Charlotte Hogarth-Jones and Hannah Ellis-Petersen investigate whether it all really is smoke and mirrors
